entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2024.10.09 edition
entry.content:
Disability claims processing, evapotranspiration, fuel forecasts, trash balloons, and Anglo-Saxons on record.

Â 

ğŸ‘‹ Job alert: Iâ€™m hiring three data reporters at The New York Times to collaborate across the newsroom. Follow that link for details and feel free to email me with any questions.

Â 

Disability claims processing. The Social Security Administration publishes monthly and annual datasets tracking each state agencyâ€™s progress processing disability claims. The datasets, which go back to October 2000, count the number of initial claims received, pending, determined, and approved by each agency during each period, as well as similar breakdowns for denial reconsiderations and continuing disability reviews. The administrationâ€™s extensive catalog of public datasets also includes several that measure the waiting involved, such as monthly average initial claim processing times, average wait times for reconsiderations, and wait times for administrative hearings. As seen in: â€œWait times for Social Security disability benefit decisions reach new highâ€ (USAFacts).

Â 

Evapotranspiration. With the goal of â€œfilling the biggest data gap in water management,â€ the OpenET project uses satellite imagery, weather data, and other sources to estimate the volume of evapotranspiration â€” â€œthe process by which water is transferred from the land to the atmosphereâ€ â€” at a 30-meter resolution across 17 states in the western US. The results are available to explore via an online map of annual cumulative evapotranspiration (2019â€“2024), as monthly datasets via Earth Engine, and through an API. [h/t Mira Rojanasakul]

Â 

Fuel forecasts. The US Energy Information Administrationâ€™s monthly Short-Term Energy Outlook provides forecasts and recent trends of energy supply, consumption, prices, and inventory. It covers a range of commodities and electricity sources, such as crude oil, coal, natural gas, gasoline, renewables, and nuclear. Starting with its September 2024 report, the outlooks have also begun to include more detailed data on biofuels, available in Table 4d of its structured datasets.

Â 

Trash balloons. Since May of this year, North Korea has floated thousands of trash-carrying balloons into South Korea. A team from the Center for Strategic and International Studiesâ€™ Beyond Parallel project has mapped 160+ known balloon landing locations, based on public sources. The mapâ€™s downloadable data indicates the each landingâ€™s date, associated â€œwave,â€ coordinates, location name, and province. As seen in: Reutersâ€™ visually immersive article on the topic. [h/t Soph Warnes]

Â 

Anglo-Saxons on record. The Prosopography of Anglo-Saxon England project â€œaims to provide structured information relating to all the recorded inhabitants of England from the late sixth to the late eleventh century.â€ Built over (relatively less) time by several teams at UK universities, PASE is â€œbased on a systematic examination of the available written sources for the period, including chronicles, saintsâ€™ Lives, charters, libri vitae, inscriptions, Domesday Book and coins.â€ The Domesday-focused portion of the project features a downloadable table of 17,000+ landholders from that manuscript, listing their name (where known), gender, description, value of holdings, and linking to details about those holdings. [h/t Derek M. Jones]

Â

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2024.09.25 edition
entry.content:
NYC evictions, open-source weather APIs, tree canopies, Canadian mines, and James Beard honorees.

Â 

NYC evictions. New York Cityâ€™s government publishes a dataset listing evictions â€œpending, scheduled and executedâ€ since 2017, updated daily. The data are â€œcompiled from the majority of New York City Marshals,â€ who are mayor-appointed officers tasked with enforcing civil court cases. Each of the 97,000+ rows indicates the eviction court case number, address, property type, eviction type, execution date, and marshal. Related: The city also publishes data on marshalsâ€™ annual eviction revenues. Also related: nycdb points to, and helps download, a range of NYC housingâ€“related datasets. As seen in: â€œSpiking Evictions Renew Calls to Reform NYC Marshals System,â€ by Patrick Spauster for City Limits.

Â 

Open-source weather APIs. Open-Meteo, an open-source project built on data from national weather services, offers a range of weather and climate APIs that are free for non-commercial use. They include weather forecasts (temperature, humidity, precipitation, wind speed, etc.), daily historical weather since 1940, climate change model outputs, marine wave forecasts, air quality assessments, and more. The project also provides bulk downloads of the underlying data and self-hosting instructions. As seen in: Jan KÃ¼hnâ€™s Historical Meteo Graphs. [h/t Giuseppe Sollazzo]

Â 

Tree canopies. The High Resolution Canopy Height Maps dataset, released in April by Meta and the World Resources Institute, estimates â€œtree canopy height at a 1-meter resolution, allowing the detection of single trees at a global scale.â€ It is available to explore online and download, and was constructed by applying machine learning techniques to satellite imagery and LiDAR data. The estimates use satellite imagery mostly from 2018â€“2020, and â€œwhen newer imagery is available, the publicly shared model can be used to detect change in canopy heights.â€ [h/t Ben Hur Pintor]

Â 

Canadian mines. Economist Clara Dallaire-Fortier has compiled a dataset of â€œmine-level estimates for the Canadian mining industry with a persistent annual coverage between 1950 and 2022,â€ based partly on historical government maps. For each of the 947 mines identified, the dataset indicates its name, location, mining companies, dates open/closed, and commodities produced. Previously: Australian mine production, 1799â€“2021 (DIP 2023.07.12).

Â 

James Beard honorees. Cody Winchester has constructed a dataset of James Beard Foundation Award semifinalists, nominees, and winners since 1991, sourced from the foundationâ€™s award-search page. For each honoree, the dataset provides their name, year, category, subcategory, and award status, plus additional category-specific variables (such as publisher for the book awards, and location for restaurant and chef awards).

Â

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2024.09.18 edition
entry.content:
Landslides, long-run economic growth, alcohol consumption, art words, and Messiâ€™s moves.

Â 

Landslides. The US Geological Survey has released a new map of landslide susceptibility, indicating the specific areas of the country (at 90-meter resolution) that are at greatest risk of slides. The map and county-level metrics are also available as structured data. To calculate the susceptibilities, Benjamin B. Mirus et al. combined data from the agencyâ€™s 3D Elevation Program and a national landslide inventory that they updated. The latter provides the location (as a single point or more detailed boundary), timing, number of fatalities, and confidence level for 610,000+ landslides (or evidence of them) in the US since the early 1900s. The researchers also consulted data from state landslide inventories published by Idaho, Maine, North Dakota, and West Virginia.

Â 

Long-run economic growth. The Maddison Project Database, based on the work of Angus Maddison (1926-2010), â€œprovides information on comparative economic growth and income levels over the very long run.â€ Its latest release includes historical per-capita GDP estimates for 169 countries, in many cases spanning several centuries. In all, the database contains 21,000+ such estimates and another 17,000+ population estimates, drawn from hundreds of sources. Previously: The Penn World Table (DIP 2016.08.17) â€” â€œincome, output, input and productivityâ€ estimates now â€œcovering 183 countries between 1950 and 2019â€ â€” and the Long-Term Productivity Database (DIP 2020.04.08).

Â 

Alcohol consumption. The National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholismâ€™s latest consumption surveillance report, published earlier this year, uses sales and shipment data to measure annual alcohol intake by beverage type (beer, wine, spirits) and state. The report and corresponding data file estimate the likely total and per-capita volumes (of the beverages and of their ethanol content) consumed each year from the 1970s through 2022. Related: Additional surveillance reports and the CDCâ€™s list of surveys gathering data on alcohol use. [h/t Millie Giles]

Â 

Art words. The Getty Vocabularies, published by the Getty Research Institute, â€œcontain structured terminology for art, architecture, decorative arts, archival materials, visual surrogates, art conservation, and bibliographic materials.â€ They provide definitions, relationships, translations, and disambiguations for a broad range of terms and entities. Their Art & Architecture Thesaurus, for example, describes 57,000+ generic concepts (e.g., lithography), while others focus on artist names, cultural objects, and geographies. The records are available several ways, including bulk downloads. [h/t Lynn Cherny]

Â 

Messiâ€™s moves. StatsBomb, a soccer/football-data company, publishes a subset of its detailed, in-play data for free. Among the offerings: Every touch, pass, dribble, and shot from Lionel Messiâ€™s 17 seasons playing for Barcelona in La Liga. Related: Carlos Menezesâ€™s tool for visualizing StatsBomb event data files. Read more: Net Gains: Inside the Beautiful Gameâ€™s Analytics Revolution, by Ryan Oâ€™Hanlon. [h/t Giuseppe Sollazzo]

Â

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2024.09.11 edition
entry.content:
The National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey, monthly crime trends, source code, Italian tax-to-charity allocations, and snakes.

Â 

ğŸ‘‹ Some exciting professional news: Iâ€™m joining The New York Times as their data editor, leading a team of data reporters whoâ€™ll be collaborating with journalists across the newsroom. Weâ€™ll be hiring! If youâ€™d like to be notified when those jobs open, please fill out this very short form.

Â 

Health and nutrition. Since 1999, CDC has been continuously fielding its National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey, interviewing and testing approximately 5,000 people in 15 different counties each year. The survey combines â€œdemographic, socioeconomic, dietary, and health-related questionsâ€ with an â€œexamination componentâ€ involving â€œmedical, dental, and physiological measurements, as well as laboratory tests administered by highly trained medical personnel.â€ Its public-access data files provide anonymized, respondent-level records and are currently available for surveys conducted through March 2020. As seen in: Catherine McDonough et al.â€™s dataset and interactive dashboard â€œexploring factors associated with prediabetes and diabetes mellitus among youth in the United States.â€

Â 

Monthly crime trends. The Real-Time Crime Index, launched last week by a team of crime-data analysts, presents a â€œsample of reported crime data from hundreds of law enforcement agencies nationwide which mimics national crime trends with as little lag and the most accuracy possible.â€ Framed as a supplement to the FBIâ€™s slow-to-update official statistics, the project provides monthly and rolling 12-month totals of reported crimes (using the FBIâ€™s UCR Part I offense categories) for the nation, individual cities, and by city population size. You can download the data and see the sources for each of the 300+ local agencies in the national sample. Read more: â€œThe Real-Time Crime Index Shows Declining Crime in 2024,â€ from project co-leader Jeff Asherâ€™s newsletter.

Â 

Source code. Software Heritage, a nonprofit initiative collaborating with UNESCO, maintains â€œthe largest public collection of source code in existenceâ€: an archive tracking 20 billion source files and 4 billion code-commits from 317 million projects from a range of public software hosts (GitHub, GitLab, BitBucket, npm, et cetera). Its Graph Dataset, which provides access to the archiveâ€™s content and internal relationships, is available via bulk downloads and APIs. [h/t Derek M. Jones]

Â 

Italian tax-to-charity allocations. Italyâ€™s â€œfive per thousandâ€ program allows taxpayers to allocate 0.5% of their income tax to certain nonprofits, research institutions, and other social-benefit organizations. The countryâ€™s Ministry of Economy and Finance has published information about 2022â€™s beneficiaries, but initially did so only via PDFs. Earlier this year, the Liberiamoli tutti! initiative converted those PDFs into structured data that list each recipient organizationâ€™s name, tax ID, category, region, province, and municipality, number of taxpayers choosing it, and amount of money allocated. The ministry has since added structured files of its own.

Â 

Snakes. SnakeDB â€” created by Sascha Steinhoff â€œafter [he] accidentally stepped into a snake in South-East Asiaâ€ â€” provides downloadable data on the maximum size, fang position, pupil shape, mode of reproduction, and toxicity of thousands of species, drawn from a broad range of sources. As seen in: Oleksandra Oskyrko et al.â€™s ReptTraits database.

Â

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2024.08.21 edition
entry.content:
H-1B lotteries, multinational corporations, California residential water supply, UK grantmakers, and Olympic medalists.

Â 

ğŸ‘‹ Data Is Plural will be taking a short break, returning to your inbox in September.

Â 

H-1B lotteries. A recent Bloomberg News investigation into the US governmentâ€™s annual H-1B lottery, a key step in allocating the countryâ€™s skilled-worker visas, finds that â€œthousands of companies got an unfair advantage by helping themselves to extra lottery tickets.â€ To reach those conclusions, the team â€œobtained data on all H-1B lottery registrations, selections, and petitions for fiscal years 2021 through 2024 after bringing a lawsuit against the Department of Homeland Security under the Freedom of Information Act.â€ Theyâ€™ve shared the records, which indicate each registrationâ€™s employer, as well as the proposed beneficiaryâ€™s gender, nationality, and birth year. For registrations that led to visa petitions, the data include additional details, such as the worksite, salary, job title, and beneficiaryâ€™s field of study. [h/t Eric Fan]

Â 

Multinational corporations. The Multinational Enterprise Information Platform, a collaboration between the OECD and the UN Statistics Division, provides publicly sourced data on the 500 multinational corporations with the largest market capitalization. Its â€œGlobal Registerâ€ dataset examines the companiesâ€™ structure, listing each subsidiaryâ€™s name, parent company, address, alternative names, and various unique identifiers. The â€œDigital Registerâ€ dataset lists all known web domains controlled by each company and assessments of those domainsâ€™ popularity. The platformâ€™s â€œMedia Monitorâ€ feature, although not downloadable, links to news articles and other webpages mentioning the companies. [h/t Annie Burns-Pieper]

Â 

California residential water supply. Marie-Philine Gross et al.â€™s dataset of residential water demand and supply in California includes the monthly volumes of water produced/sold by 404 of the stateâ€™s water suppliers, covering 2013â€“2021. The researchers extracted, standardized, and cleaned the data from the stateâ€™s mandatory annual reports, which collect thousands of data points from each supplier. They also added contextual information, such as climatic data (monthly local precipitation, temperature, and drought severity) and each supplierâ€™s hydrologic region.

Â 

UK grantmakers. The UK Grantmaking initiative â€œis a unique cross-sector collaboration betweenâ€ several major organizations in the field. Their downloadable dataset provides information about 12,000+ trusts, foundations, charities, and other grantmakers for financial year 2022-23, based on records from government regulators. The dataset lists each organizationâ€™s name, government-assigned ID, location, category, registration date, income, spending totals, net assets, and more. Previously: UK grants via 360Giving (DIP 2018.12.05). [h/t Giuseppe Sollazzo]

Â 

Olympic medalists. The European Data Journalism Networkâ€™s Giorgio Comai has used Wikipedia and Wikidata to create a series of datasets listing the name, birth date, sex, and birthplace of Summer Olympic medalists. Comai has mapped the birthplace coordinates and, for Europe-born medalists, linked them to their NUTS regions. The project focuses on the 2024 and 2020 Summer Olympics but also provides provisional data for other recent iterations. [h/t Federico Caruso]

Â

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2024.08.14 edition
entry.content:
The Freedmanâ€™s Bank, recreational boating accidents, Western water rights, real-time UK voter registrations, and watching grass grow.

Â 

ğŸ“¬ Reader Alexandra F has used the ancient shipwreck data featured in DIP 2024.07.10 to build a series of maps for each historical sub-period. (Have you published something with data you found via DIP? Click here to let me know.)

Â 

The Freedmanâ€™s Bank. The Freedmanâ€™s Savings and Trust Company was chartered by Congress in 1865, toward the end of the Civil War, to provide banking services to formerly enslaved Americans. â€œThough the bank achieved some early successes, it failed catastrophically in 1874, destroying the savings of a broad swath of newly freed black citizens,â€ write Malcolm Wardlaw and Virginia Traweek, who have constructed several datasets based on handwritten records preserved by the federal government. One dataset lists 5,000+ transactions from 500+ accountsâ€™ â€œpassbooksâ€, indicating the account holder, city, transaction type, date, and amount. Another lists 40,000+ accountsâ€™ final balances at the time of the bankâ€™s failure. Read more: Wardlaw and Traweekâ€™s studies analyzing the records.

Â 

Recreational boating accidents. In the US, recreational boaters must notify state authorities soon after any incident involving a death, serious injury, disappearance, or substantial damage. The authorities relay those notifications to the Coast Guard, which stores them in its centralized Boating Accident Report Database. The Data Liberation Project (which, customary disclosure, I run) filed a FOIA request for the database and, earlier this week, published the records it received. The data describe 58,000+ boating accidents, 78,000+ vessels, 8,900+ deaths, and 36,000+ injuries from 2009 to 2023, although a few states and territories withheld their incidents from disclosure. Read more: The Data Liberation Projectâ€™s introductory documentation.

Â 

Western water rights. Matthew D. Lisk et al. have compiled and standardized a dataset of water rights records â€” key documents in the allocation of the scarce resource â€” in the Western United States. Drawing on raw data collected from 11 states, the harmonized dataset â€œprovides consistent unique identifiers for each spatial unit of water management across the domain, unique identifiers for each water right record, and a consistent categorization scheme that puts each water right record into one of 7 broad use categories.â€ Those categories: irrigation, domestic, livestock, fish, industrial, environmental, and other. The authors have also published a set of shapefiles outlining each water management areaâ€™s boundaries.

Â 

Real-time UK voter registrations. The UK governmentâ€™s voter registration statistics dashboard updates hundreds of times per day. It provides downloadable data on the number of online applications in each five-minute interval in the past 24 hours and daily counts broken down by online vs. paper applications, age group, elector type, and nation. [h/t Giuseppe Sollazzo]

Â 

ğŸ‘‹ The first two links in the item below seem to be returning HTTP errors this morning. In case theyâ€™re still not working when you receive the newsletter, try these archived versions: 1, 2.

Â 

Watching grass grow. The Jornada Experimental Range, run by the USDAâ€™s Agricultural Research Service, â€œis one of the longest serving laboratories focused on rangelands and drylands in the world.â€ Located north of Las Cruces, N.M., the site has operating since the 1910s. A few years ago, Erica Christensen et al. published a dataset of grass and shrub growth within 122 one-meter-by-one-meter squares on the range from 1915 to 2016, containing roughly 200,000 observations.

Â

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2024.08.07 edition
entry.content:
State/local government employment, railroad incidents, Irelandâ€™s gender pay gaps, weather balloons, and art auction sales.

Â 

ğŸ“¬ Reader Jeremy B. Merrill recently used the WildChat Dataset, featured in DIP 2024.05.15, to analyze what people really ask AI chatbots. (Have you published something with data you found via DIP? Click here to let me know.)

Â 

State/local government employment. Every year, the Census Bureau sends its Annual Survey of Public Employment & Payroll to all 50 state governments and 90,000+ local governments, requesting employee counts and payroll totals. The surveyâ€™s public datasets provide those figures for each government unit, broken down by several dozen â€œfunctional categoriesâ€ (such as â€œHighwaysâ€, â€œFinancial Administrationâ€, and â€œHospitalsâ€). As seen in: The Marshall Projectâ€™s guide to using the data to examine declines in prison staffing, part of the organizationâ€™s new Investigate This! initiative; theyâ€™ve also aggregated the raw records into a spreadsheet of annual state totals. [h/t David Eads]

Â 

Railroad incidents. Since last August, the Federal Railroad Administration has been rolling out a new portal for its safety data. Through it, you can find datasets on incidents and accidents involving railroad equipment, incidents at grade crossings, and reported injuries and illnesses, as well as dashboards and reports on related topics. The grade crossing dataset, for instance, lists 246,000+ incidents since 1975; it indicates each incidentâ€™s date, railroad, crossing identifier, nearest station, number of injuries, vehicle and train speeds, and much more. Previously: Blocked rail crossings (DIP 2023.05.10).

Â 

Irelandâ€™s gender pay gaps. Irelandâ€™s Gender Pay Gap Information Act requires certain-sized companies to report their differences pay for men versus women. â€œWhile plans are in place to create a central portal (similar to that in the UK) to collate this information, such a database does not exist yet,â€ writes Jennifer Keane, who has built PayGap.ie to fill the void. For each company and year, the projectâ€™s database lists the metrics the Act requires â€” mean and median hourly pay gaps, percentages of men and women paid bonuses, proportion of employees in each pay quartile for each gender, among others â€” plus a link to the companyâ€™s public report.

Â 

Weather balloons. When a weather balloon rises into the atmosphere, it carries a radiosonde to record the temperature, pressure, wind speed, humidity, and other measurements. NOAAâ€™s Integrated Global Radiosonde Archive â€œconsists of radiosonde and pilot balloon observations from more than 2,800 globally distributed stations,â€ some dating back to the early 1900s. SondeHub, meanwhile, tracks hundreds of weather balloons a day in real-time, thanks to a community-run network of 1,400+ receiver stations. You can browse the flight paths and detailed measurements online, and access the data via download and API. [h/t Michael Allen]

Â 

Art auction sales. Kangsan Lee et al. have compiled a dataset of â€œ34,200 auction sales records, including images, artistsâ€™ attributes, and market information, encompassing 590 living contemporary artists spanning 17 years (1996 to 2012) across 23 countries.â€ It includes the artistâ€™s name, nationality, and birth year; the artworkâ€™s name, year, medium, and dimensions; the auction date, house, initial estimates, and final sale price; and more. The sales information comes from Blouin, which the researchers â€œcross-check[ed] with publicly available auction house data at the time, such as Christieâ€™s and Sothebyâ€™s.â€

Â

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2024.07.31 edition
entry.content:
Ballots cast, hurricane evacuation orders, networked scholarship, people surveyed since 1979, and NPRâ€™s weekly quiz show.

Â 

Ballots cast. â€œElectronic records of actual ballots cast (cast vote records) are available to the public in some jurisdictions,â€ Shiro Kuriwaki et al. write. â€œHowever, they have been released in a variety of formats and have not been independently evaluated.â€ So the researchers have constructed a standardized dataset representing 40.7 million (anonymous) ballots in the November 2020 general election, spanning 352 counties across 20 states. Each of the 160 million rows corresponds to a voterâ€™s choice in a particular race and indicates the precinct, legislative district, office in question, candidate selected, and candidateâ€™s party. The initial release, which the authors use to analyze ticket-splitting patterns, covers votes for president, Senate, House, governor, and state legislature. [h/t Derek Willis]

Â 

Hurricane evacuation orders. Harsh Anand et al.â€™s Hurricane Evacuation Order Database â€œis a comprehensive and standardized database of evacuation orders issued by state and local government officials in response to the hurricanes that impacted the United States between 2014 and 2023.â€ To build it, the authors combed through government websites, official social media, news reports, and other sources. The database covers 27 storms and several types of announcements: state-of-emergency declarations, mandatory evacuations, voluntary evacuations, and the lifting of those orders. For each announcement, the database indicates the order type, date/time announced, date/time effective, counties affected, and evacuation area.

Â 

Scholarship, networked. OpenAlex, â€œa free and open catalog of the global research system,â€ has compiled data on more than 250 million scholarly works â€” and has linked those works to structured information about their authors, institutions, publishers, funders, topics. The data are available to search online, to download in bulk, and via API. As seen in: Aliakbar Akbaritabar et al.â€™s â€œBilateral flows and rates of international migration of scholars for 210 countries for the period 1998-2020â€ and Philippe Mongeon et al.â€™s dataset of scholarsâ€™ Twitter/X usernames.

Â 

People surveyed since 1979. The Bureau of Labor Statisticsâ€™ NLSY79 survey has interviewed the same people dozens of times since 1979. It began with a â€œnationally representative sample of 12,686 young men and womenâ€; more than four decades later, 6,000+ interviewees are still responding to the projectâ€™s biennial inquiries. The survey asks about a range of topics, including education, employment, health, dating, marriage, children, attitudes, and substance abuse. Public-use data are available to download and through the agencyâ€™s NLS Investigator tool. Related: The agencyâ€™s other national longitudinal surveys. [h/t Prashant Bharadwaj et al.]

Â 

Wait Wait. Linh Pham considers himself â€œthe unofficial scorekeeperâ€ of Wait Waitâ€¦ Donâ€™t Tell Me!, NPRâ€™s weekly quiz show. Since 2007, heâ€™s been maintaining a structured database that describes Wait Waitâ€™s episodes, venues, hosts, guests, panelists, and more. Pham provides the data via API, and also publishes charts and automated reports, such this list of panelists who won their debut appearances. [h/t Cody Winchester]

Â

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2024.07.24 edition
entry.content:
News homepages, human rights scores, commercial zones, national park species, and Australia shipwrecks.

Â 

News homepages, archived. Since launching in March 2022, homepages.news has archived millions of screenshots, performance audits, robots.txt files, accessibility trees, and hyperlink lists from the homepages of 1,100+ news sites. The open-source project, run by journalist Ben Welsh, provides bulk data for each of those assets. The screenshots themselves are stored on the Internet Archive; you can also view the latest screenshots from all the sites on one page. To date, the publications span 32 countries and 17 languages. Related: Welsh and volunteer Alex Garcia are using the robots.txt data to track which sites block OpenAI, Google AI, and Common Crawl â€” findings that have been cited widely.

Â 

Human rights scores. The CIRIGHTS project aims â€œto create numerical measures for every internationally recognized human right for all countries of the world.â€ The team has developed a detailed guide to scoring each governmentâ€™s record on dozens of such rights, such as freedom of religion, womenâ€™s political rights, freedom from extrajudicial killings, the right to a fair trial, and â€œreasonable limitsâ€ on working hours. For each year from 1981 to 2021, the projectâ€™s scorers have rated each country on each right, generally on a three-point scale, based on information in the US State Departmentâ€™s Country Reports on Human Rights Practices, Amnesty Internationalâ€™s annual reports, and similar sources. The resulting dataset includes those scores, as well as several summary metrics.

Â 

Commercial zones. Byeonghwa Jeong et al. have constructed a dataset estimating the geographic boundaries of 23,000+ commercial zones in 69 metro areas in the US and Canada. To build it, they used data on retail and office locations from OpenStreetMap, and on job density from the US Census Bureauâ€™s Longitudinal Employer-Household Dynamics program (DIP 2021.05.26) and Statistics Canada. For each detected commercial zone, the dataset provides its outline, total area, a score of its relative concentration (on which the zone comprising most of Manhattan scored the highest), its MSA, and the street at its centroid.

Â 

National park species. The National Park Serviceâ€™s NPSpecies portal â€œdocuments our knowledge about the occurrence and status of speciesâ€ on the agencyâ€™s lands. For each NPS-managed area, you can download a list of the species, their scientific and common names, occurrence status (present, probably present, unconfirmed), nativeness, conservation status, and more. Related: Noting that â€œmany of the observations in NPSpecies remain unverified and the lists are often outdated,â€ Benjamin J. LaFrance et al. have created an updated dataset for amphibian species, which they checked against other sources and verified with regional experts.

Â 

Australia shipwrecks. The Western Australia Museum hosts a range of datasets, including details concerning 1,600+ local shipwrecks and 30,000+ artifacts recovered from them. The shipwreck dataset lists each shipâ€™s builder, construction materials, owner, cargo, wreck location, date wrecked, known deaths, date found, and more. Previously: Ancient shipwrecks (DIP 2024.07.10). [h/t Kristin Milton]

entry.content:
Federal inmate complaints, corporate AI activity, East Asia building outlines, US coral reefs, and ancient shipwrecks.

Â 

Federal inmate complaints. The Federal Bureau of Prisonsâ€™ Administrative Remedy Program â€œallow[s] an inmate to seek formal review of an issue relating to any aspect of his/her own confinement.â€ In October 2022, the Data Liberation Project (which, disclosure, I run) filed a FOIA request seeking records from the agency database that tracks those complaints. In response, BOP last month provided data on 1.78 million complaint and appeal submissions filed from January 2000 through late May 2024, spanning nearly 1 million distinct cases. The records, published yesterday with the help of volunteers, indicate when each filing was received, its relevant case number, complaint subject, facility where the issue occurred, case status, status update date, reasons for rejection/closure, and other details.

Â 

Corporate AI activity. The Private-Sector AI Indicators dataset, from Georgetown Universityâ€™s Emerging Technology Observatory, provides â€œa diverse range of indicators of AI-related activity for hundreds of companies worldwide, from startups to multinationals.â€ For each of the 670+ companies included, the dataset counts the number of AI-related research articles published by its employees (disaggregated by topic), AI-related patents filed (by application area and use-case), and workforce (overall and those estimated to be AI-involved). It also lists each companyâ€™s main location, sector, growth stage, and description, as well as aliases, stock listings, and identifiers in several external data sources. See also: An interactive version of the database. [h/t Zach Arnold]

Â 

East Asia building outlines. Recent years have seen the development of ambitious datasets that provide the outlines of buildings by the millions. For instance, from the archives: buildings in the US (DIP 2018.07.18), Africa (DIP 2021.08.25), and Canada and New Zealand (DIP 2019.09.25). In the Journal of Remote Sensing, however, Qian Shi et al. note a relative lack of such data for buildings in East Asia, which the authors attribute â€œto the more complex distribution of buildings and the scarcity of auxiliary dataâ€. As an antidote, theyâ€™ve generated a dataset that outlines more than 280 million buildings in 2,800+ cities across China, Japan, South Korea, North Korea, and Mongolia.

Â 

US coral reefs. The National Coral Reef Monitoring Program collects scientific and socioeconomic/attitude survey data related to the coral reefs offshore of the continental United States, Hawaii, and US territories. It provides the data through public visualizations as well as download tools and raw files. The scientific data include species-level coral cover, colony density, bleaching prevalence, and disease rates; fish populations; water alkalinity and dissolved inorganic carbon levels; and more. [h/t Gary Price]

Â 

Ancient shipwrecks. The Summary Geodatabase of Shipwrecks 1500BCE-1500CE merges two catalogs of ancient wrecks: one from the Oxford Roman Economy Project and one from Harvardâ€™s Mapping Past Societies project. Building on scholarly research by Toby Parker, Julia Strauss, and others, the combined effort includes 1,900+ known wrecks, listing (where known) their coordinates, depth, estimated time period when wrecked, year discovered, cargo, and more.
